title: 110_hr913
content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit is 25% of the expenditures, up to a maximum of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. The "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. This includes bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof connections, protecting openings from debris, and safeguarding exterior doors and garages in qualified dwelling units located in specific states with assessed values below $1,000,000. The "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures in specific states. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector and include labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of the property. The original installation and inspection costs for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures are considered for tax purposes. A new item is added to the table of sections for subpart A of the tax code. The amendments made by this section introduce a new business-related credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The hurricane and tornado mitigation credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum credit of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof strength, creating water barriers, enhancing roof durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. The hurricane and tornado mitigation credit offers a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include strengthening roofs, creating water barriers, enhancing durability, bracing walls, reinforcing roof connections, and protecting openings from debris. Qualified place of business must be assessed at a value less than $5,000,000 in a qualified State. The taxpayer must complete onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property in a manner approved by a State-certified inspector for expenditures to be considered. Labor costs related to onsite work are eligible, as well as inspection costs. The taxpayer's qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures during the taxable year include inspection costs for preparation, assembly, or installation. Conforming amendments to the tax code include a new hurricane and tornado mitigation credit. The amendments made by this section regarding the Hurricane and tornado mitigation credit apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
